case_vignette: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, his scalp itches or he notices a burning sensation. He had a mole removed on his right forearm 5 years ago. He is a retired winemaker. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple rough patches on his scalp. A photograph is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been noticing changes on my scalp skin for the past three months, and when I scrape off the crust, it keeps coming back in a few days. Sometimes my scalp itches or burns too.
Is this itching and crusting primarily localized to your scalp?
Yes, the itching and crusting are just on my scalp.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 68-year-old man.
Have you been taking any new medications recently?
No, I haven't started any new medications recently.

Does anyone in your family have a history of similar scalp symptoms?

**Final Diagnosis:** Seborrheic Dermatitis.
